Problem:
Consider a system governed by the linear differential equation \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\), where D is a constant matrix. The system undergoes analysis under the influence of a transformation, \\( g(x) = Cx \\), with C being another constant matrix, applied at an arbitrary time \\( t_0 \\).

If \\( g(x) \\) is applied to a vector \\( x_0 \\) at t = 0, which then evolves based on \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\) without further intervention, will the state \\( x(t) \\) at t = T be equivalent to the state obtained if \\( x_0 \\) was evolved under \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\) up to t = T without applying \\( g(x) \\)?
Explanation: The transformation \\( g(x) = Cx \\) modifies the initial condition, thereby changing the trajectory of the system. Although both are linear transformations, the change in the initial state due to C will yield a different state at any future time T compared to the untransformed initial condition, unless C is the identity matrix or commutes perfectly with D.
